newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong gold inactivity making dealers nervous.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong gold inactivity making dealers nervous.

text.p: Next to no activity in the Hong Kong gold market had some gold dealers worrying about their jobs on Wednesday, with some repeating rumours of an impending clearout of ranks in the colony if things do not pick up soon.
"It's a very depressing time for the market," said one Hong Kong source.
"There are a lot of stories about cutbacks in terms of headcount at the banks," he said.
Wednesday activity was indicative of the bearish feelings. Gold barely moved, with some traders likening the day to a tennis match between dealers with nothing better to do.
Bullion opened at US$381.00/50, and closed at US$380.80/381.30.

"It's starting to drift a little bit," said another source. "There was some German trade selling, and a little bit of a battle between dealers, just punting each against each other. Otherwise -- nothing."
The only movement in the local tael market was down, opening of HK$3,512 and closing at HK$3,510.
The carryover charge at the Chinese Gold and Silver Exchange Society for 10 taels was -8.
